title: 113_s1484
content: The Act may be cited as the "Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013 defines the term "Authority" as the Sabine River Authority of Texas and "Federal land" as National Forest System land within the Sabine National Forest and Toledo Bend Project boundary in Texas, including certain additional Federal land occupied by Forest Service campgrounds. The Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013 defines "non-Federal land" as private land adjacent to Sabine National Forest to be acquired by the Sabine River Authority of Texas and mutually agreed upon by the Secretary. The Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013 defines "non-Federal land" as private land adjacent to Sabine National Forest to be acquired by the Sabine River Authority of Texas and mutually agreed upon by the Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary is defined as the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Chief of the Forest Service. The Toledo Bend Project refers to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission project numbered 2305, and the wilderness area is the Indian Mounds Wilderness Area in Sabine National Forest designated by the Texas Wilderness Act of 1984. Wilderness candidate land refers to the surface estate of land adjacent to the wilderness area. The Indian Mounds Wilderness Area in Sabine National Forest, designated by the Texas Wilderness Act of 1984, includes wilderness candidate land, which is the surface estate of land adjacent to the wilderness area to be agreed upon by the Authority and the Secretary. SEC. 3. LAND EXCHANGE, SABINE NATIONAL FOREST. In exchange for non-Federal land, wilderness candidate land, and any cash payment, the Secretary will convey all US interests in Federal land to the Authority, subject to existing rights. Within 180 days of enactment, an appraisal of surface estates will be completed according to standards. The Secretary will complete an appraisal of the surface estate of Federal land, non-Federal land, and wilderness candidate land according to specific standards and taking into account any restrictions on land use imposed by a restrictive covenant. The Secretary will determine the value of Federal land considering restrictions imposed by a covenant. Surveys will establish the acreage and description of land to be exchanged. Costs will be split between the Authority and the Secretary. Cash equalization will ensure an equal value exchange. The land exchange will be conducted on an equal value basis, with costs shared equally between the Authority and the Secretary. Cash equalization may be used to equalize the values of the exchanged land, exceeding statutory limits. Any cash equalization payment received by the Secretary will be handled accordingly. The land exchange involves equalization payments exceeding statutory limits, with funds deposited into the Sisk Act fund for land acquisition by the Secretary. Title to non-Federal land conveyed must be acceptable to the Secretary. The Secretary can acquire land for the National Forest System without further appropriation. The title of non-Federal land must meet the Secretary's approval and conform to the Attorney General's standards. The deed must reserve any subsurface mineral estate owned by the United States. The deed conveying Federal land to the Authority must reserve any subsurface mineral estate owned by the United States, including oil, gas, rock, sand, and gravel. The deed must also include a covenant that the land be used in a manner consistent with adjacent National Forest System or wilderness area land, remain unsubdivided, and not be used for commercial, residential, or industrial development. The Authority may operate Forest Service campgrounds and maintain them as per Federal Energy Regulatory Commission authorization. Congress intends for the land exchange to be completed within a specified timeframe. The Forest Service campgrounds conveyed under subsection (a) must be operated and maintained in accordance with Federal Energy Regulatory Commission authorization. Congress aims for the land exchange to be completed within one year of this Act's enactment. SEC. 4. BOUNDARY ADJUSTMENT, INDIAN MOUNDS WILDERNESS AREA, SABINE NATIONAL FOREST. Boundary Adjustment for the Indian Mounds Wilderness Area in Sabine National Forest involves excluding existing wilderness area land within the Toledo Bend Project and including acquired wilderness candidate land to be designated as wilderness. Legal descriptions and maps are required for these adjustments. The Secretary will designate acquired wilderness candidate land as wilderness and part of the National Wilderness Preservation System. A map and legal description of boundary changes resulting from a land exchange must be filed with the relevant committees. The filed map and legal description will have the same legal effect as if included in the Act. The Senate will provide a map and legal description of boundary changes resulting from a land exchange, which will have the same legal effect as if included in the Act. The map and legal description will be available for public inspection in Forest Service offices.
